Noork At first he saw nothing out of the ordinary. Apparently there was no stir of life along that leaf-shadowed way. And then he caught a glimpse of blurring shadowy shapes, blotches of cottony mist that blended all too well with the foliage. One of the things from the island in the Lake of Uzdon moved, and he saw briefly the bottom of a foot dirtied with the mud of the trail. Noork squinted. So the Misty Ones were not entirely invisible. Pain was growing in his numbed arm now, but as it came so came strength. He climbed further out on the great branch to where sticky and overripe fruit hung heavy. With a grin he locked his legs upon the forking of the great limb and filled his arms with fruit. A barrage of the juicy fruit blanketed the misty shapes. Stains spread and grew. Patchy outlines took on a new color and sharpness. Noork found that he was pelting a half-dozen hooded and robed creatures whose arms and legs numbered the same as his own, and the last remnant of superstitious fear instilled in his bruised brain by the shaggy Vasads vanished. The face was that of Doctor Von Mark the treacherous Nazi scientist that Stephen Dietrich had trailed across space to Sekk! But Noork knew nothing of that chase. The man's face seemed familiar, and hateful, but that was all he remembered. "I see you have come from the island," said the Doctor. "Perhaps you can tell me the secret of this invisible material I wear. With the secret of invisibility I, Karl Von Mark, can again conquer Earth and make the Fatherland invincible." "I do not understand too well," said Noork hesitantly. "Are we enemies? There is so much I have forgotten." He regarded the brutal face thoughtfully. "Perhaps you know from what valley the great bird brought me," he said. "Or perhaps the other bird brought you here." Von Mark's blue eyes widened and then he roared with a great noise that was intended to be mirth. His foot slammed harder into Noork's defenseless ribs. your guards, then." The priest laughed. "We also have robes of invisibility," he said, "and the sacred window of Uzdon before our eyes." He snarled suddenly at the silent figure of the white man. "Down on your knees, guard, and show me your face before I kill you!" Noork raised his sword. "Take my hood off if you dare, priest," he offered. The burly priest's answer was a bellow of rage and a lunge forward of his sword arm. Their swords clicked together and slid apart with the velvety smoothness of bronze on bronze. Noork's blade bit a chunk from the priest's conical shield, and in return received a slashing cut that drew blood from left shoulder to elbow. The fighting grew more furious as the priest pressed the attack. He was a skilled swordsman and only the superior agility of the white man's legs kept Noork away from that darting priestly blade. Even so his robe was slashed in a dozen places and blood reddened his bronzed body. Once he slipped in a puddle of foul cavern water and only by the slightest of margins did he escape death by the priest's weapon. The priest was tiring rapidly, however. The soft living of the temple, and the rich wines and over-cooked meats that served to pad his paunch so well with fat, now served to rob him of breath. A moment later saw the three of them climbing along the limb to the bole of the tree and so to the jungle matted ground outside the wall. Text:
short powerful bow that Gurn had given him, and rained arrows down upon the cowering robed creatures. And the monsters fled. They fled down the trail or faded away into the jungle. All but one of them. The arrow had pierced a vital portion of this Misty One's body. He fell and moved no more. A moment later Noork was ripping the stained cloak and hood from the fallen creature, curious to learn what ghastly brute-thing hid beneath them. His lip curled at what he saw. The Misty One was almost like himself. His skin was not so golden as that of the other men of Zuran, and his forehead was low and retreating in a bestial fashion. Upon his body there was more hair, and his face was made hideous with swollen colored scars that formed an irregular design. He wore a sleeveless tunic of light green and his only weapons were two long knives and a club. "So," said Noork, "the men of the island prey upon their own kind. And the Temple of Uzdon in the lake is guarded by cowardly warriors like this." Noork shrugged his shoulders and set off at a mile-devouring pace down the game trail toward the lake where the Temple of the Skull and its unseen guardians lay. Once he stopped at a leaf-choked pool to wash the stains from the dead man's foggy robe. The jungle was thinning out. Noork's teeth flashed as he lifted the drying fabric of the mantle and donned it. For a huge gleaming bird had carried him in its talons to the top of the cliff above their valley and from the rock fire had risen to devour the great bird. Somehow he had been flung clear and escaped the death of the mysterious bird-thing. And in his delirium he had babbled the words that caused the apish Vasads to name him Noork. Now he repeated them aloud. "New York," he said, "good ol' New York." The girl heard. She looked upward fearfully, her rounded bare arm going back to the bow slung across her shoulder. Swiftly she fitted an arrow and stepped back against the friendly bole of a shaggy barked jungle giant. Noork grinned. "Tako, woman," he greeted her. "Tako," she replied fearfully. "Who speaks to Tholon Sarna? Be you hunter or escaped slave?" "A friend," said Noork simply. "It was I who killed the spotted narl last night when it attacked you." Doubtfully the girl put away her bow. Her fingers, however, were never far from the hilt of her hunting dagger. They rolled over and over down the shadowy stair, the stone smashing at their softer flesh unmercifully. For a moment the battling men brought up with a jolt as the obstruction of the first guard's corpse arrested their downward course, and then they jolted and jarred onward again from blood-slippery step to blood-slippery step. The sword clattered from the guardian Misty One's clutch and in the same instant Noork's steel fingers snapped the neck of the other man with a pistol-like report. The limp body beneath him struggled no more. He sprang to his feet and became aware of a torch-lighted doorway but a half-dozen paces further down along the descending shaft of steps. In a moment, he thought, the fellows of this guard would come charging out, swords in hand. They could not have failed to hear the struggle on the stairs of stone, he reasoned, for here the noise and confusion of the upper temple was muted to a murmur. So it was that he ran quickly to the door, in his hand the sword that had dropped from the dead man's fingers, and sprang inside, prepared to battle there the Misty Ones, lest one escape to give the alarm. There were several of the hooded cloaks hanging from pegs wedged into the crevices of the chamber's wall, their outlines much plainer here in the artificial light of the flickering torch. The matter of his disguise thus taken care of he dragged the two bodies from the stairway and hid them beneath their own fouled robes in the chamber of the sleeping guards. Pools of foul black water dotted the uneven floor and reflected back faintly the light of the two sputtering torches beside the entrance. Noork lifted the short, broad-bladed sword that swung in its sheath at his belt and let it drop back into place with a satisfying whisper of flexible leather on steel. He looked toward the east where lay the mysterious long lake of the Misty Ones. "Some day," he said reflectively, "I am going to visit the island of the unseen evil beings who stole away your friends. Perhaps after I have taken you to your brother's hidden village, and from there to your city of Grath...." He smiled. The girl did not answer. His keen ears, now that he was no longer speaking, caught the scuffing of feet into the jungle behind him. He turned quickly to find the girl had vanished, and with an instinctive reflex of motion he flung himself to one side into the dense wall of the jungle. [Transcriber's Note: This etext was produced from Planet Stories Summer 1945. Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.] Beyond earth swings that airless pocked mass of fused rock and gray volcanic dust that we know as Luna. Of this our naked eyes assure us. But of the smaller satellite, hidden forever from the mundane view by Luna's bulk, we know little. Small is Sekk, that second moon, less than five hundred miles in diameter, but the period of its revolution is thirty two hours, and its meaner mass retains a breathable atmosphere. There is life on Sekk, life that centers around the sunken star-shaped cavity where an oval lake gleams softly in the depths. And the eleven radiating tips of the starry abyss are valleys green with jungle growth. In one of those green valleys the white savage that the Vasads called Noork squatted in the ample crotch of a jungle giant and watched the trail forty feet below. For down there moved alertly a golden skinned girl, her only weapons a puny polished bow of yellow wood and a sheathed dagger. He walked along the row until he reached the slave's bent back, and he knew by the sudden tightening of the man's shoulder muscles that his presence was known. He looked down and saw that his feet made clear-cut depressions in the soft rich soil of the field. "Continue to work," he said to the young man. "Do not be too surprised at what I am about to tell you, Rold." He paused and watched the golden man's rather stupid face intently. "I am not a Misty One," Noork said. "I killed the owner of this strange garment I wear yesterday on the mainland. I have come to rescue the girl, Tholon Sarna, of whom you spoke." Rold's mouth hung open but his hard blunt fingers continued to work. "The Misty Ones, then," he said slowly, "are not immortal demons!" He nodded his long-haired head. "They are but men. They too can die." "If you will help me, Rold," said Noork, "to rescue the girl and escape from the island I will take you along." Rold was slow in answering. He had been born on the island and yet his people were from the valley city of Konto. He knew that they would welcome the news that the Misty Ones were not demons. And the girl from the enemy city of Grath was beautiful. Perhaps she would love him for helping to rescue her

Shortly after midday Noork felt the oozy slime of the marshy lowlands of the mainland beneath his paddle and the dugout ran ashore in the grassy inlet for which they had been heading. His palms were blistered and the heavy robes he yet wore were soaked with sweat. "Once we reach the jungle," he told the girl, "off come these robes. I am broiled alive." Suddenly Noork froze in his tracks. He thrust the girl behind him. "Misty Ones!" he hissed to Rold. "They crouch among the reeds. They carry nets and clubs to trap us." Rold turned back toward the boat with Noork and Sarna close at his heels. But the Misty Ones were upon them and by sheer numbers they bore them to the ground. Noork's mightier muscles smashed more than one hooded face but in the end he too lay smothered beneath the nets and bodies of the enemy. A misty shape came to stand beside these three new captives as they were stripped of their robes. His foot nudged at Noork's head curiously and a guttural voice commanded the shield be removed. Two words linked Noork with the past, the two words that the Vasads had slurred into his name: New York. And the battered wrist watch, its crystal and hands gone, were all that remained of his Earthly garb. Noork paddled the long flat dugout strongly away from the twilight shore toward the shadowy loom of the central island. Though he could not remember ever having held a paddle before he handled the ungainly blade well. After a time the clumsy prow of the craft rammed into a yielding cushion of mud, and Noork pulled the dugout out of the water into the roofing shelter of a clump of drooping trees growing at the water's edge. Sword in hand he pushed inward from the shore and ended with a smothered exclamation against an unseen wall. Trees grew close up to the wall and a moment later he had climbed out along a horizontal branch beyond the wall's top, and was lowering his body with the aid of a braided leather rope to the ground beyond. He was in a cultivated field his feet and hands told him. And perhaps half a mile away, faintly illumined by torches and red clots of bonfires, towered a huge weathered white skull! As he circled the curving inner wall a foul dank odor reached his sensitive nostrils, and his eyes searched for its origin. "None are to pass save the priests," spoke a voice from nowhere gruffly. "The High Priest knows that we of the temple guards covet the most beautiful of the slave women, but we are not to see them until the sacrifice is chosen." Noork moved backward a pace. He grumbled something inaudible and drew his sword. Before him the two swords slowly drew aside. In that instant Noork attacked. His keen sword, whetted to razor sharpness on abrasive bits of rock, bit through the hidden neck and shoulder of the guard on his right hand, and with the same forward impetus of attack he smashed into the body of the startled guard on his left. llm_response:
The user is asking for the plot of a story. The RAG system responded by stating it cannot provide the plot due to insufficient information in the retrieved graph. While this is a truthful statement about the system's limitations *based on its retrieval*, it's not a particularly helpful or user-friendly response.

Here's a breakdown of why the response could be improved and how:

## Evaluation of the Current Response:

**Strengths:**

*   **Honesty:** It directly addresses the limitation of the retrieved data.
*   **Clarity:** It clearly states *why* it cannot answer the question (insufficient information, lack of connections/events).

**Weaknesses:**

*   **Unhelpful:** It simply states it can't do something without offering any alternative or guidance.
*   **Lacks Empathy/User-Friendliness:** Phrases like "I am sorry, but I cannot" can sound a bit robotic.
*   **Doesn't Guide the User:** It doesn't tell the user what *kind* of information would be needed, or what the user could do differently.
*   **Assumes Graph is the *Only* Source:** While the RAG system might be designed to work primarily with a graph, users might not understand this constraint.

## Improvement Suggestions:

The core of the improvement lies in making the response more helpful and guiding the user towards a successful interaction.

**1. Acknowledge the Request and Explain the Limitation More Constructively:**

*   **Instead of:** "I am sorry, but I cannot provide the plot of the story as the information retrieved from the graph is insufficient."
*   **Consider:** "I understand you're looking for the plot of the story. However, the information I have access to right now is limited to a list of characters and groups, and doesn't include details about their interactions or the sequence of events that make up the plot."

**2. Clearly State What Information is Needed (and how the user might provide it):**

*   **Add:** "To tell you the plot, I would need information that describes the storyline, key events, character motivations, conflicts, and resolutions."
*   **Or, if the system can potentially *process* more information (even if not currently retrieved):** "If you have more details about the story's events, connections between characters, or a summary of the narrative, please provide them, and I'll do my best to piece together the plot."

**3. Offer Alternative Actions or Information:**

*   **If the system *can* provide *some* related information:** "While I can't give you the full plot, I can tell you about the characters and groups mentioned in the data I have. For example, I can list the characters if you'd like."
*   **If the system relies on specific input formats or sources:** "Could you please specify which story you're referring to, or provide a text summary of it? My current data only contains character names and group affiliations, which isn't enough to construct a narrative."
*   **If the RAG system is meant to access a broader knowledge base but failed this time:** "I'm having trouble finding a detailed plot summary with the current information. Would you like me to try searching for a general plot summary of [story name, if it was identified] from a broader source?" (This assumes the system has a fallback mechanism).

**4. Be More Empathetic and User-Centric:**

*   Use softer language.
*   Focus on what *can* be done or what is *needed* for success, rather than just what *can't* be done.

---

## Example of an Improved Response:

Here are a few options, depending on the RAG system's capabilities:

**Option 1 (If the system can list characters but not plot):**

> "I understand you're interested in the plot of the story. Unfortunately, the information I was able to retrieve only includes a list of characters and groups, and doesn't contain the narrative details or sequence of events needed to describe the plot.
>
> However, I *can* provide you with a list of the characters and groups identified in the data. Would you like me to do that?"

**Option 2 (If the system is designed to process more narrative input):**

> "I'm sorry, but I couldn't find enough information to construct the plot of the story. The data I have currently only lists characters and groups without detailing their interactions or the story's events.
>
> To help me tell you the plot, could you please provide more context? For example, you could tell me:
>
> *   The title of the story.
> *   A brief description of the story's main events.

llm_response:
You are an AI assistant designed to answer user queries by synthesizing information from a knowledge graph. Your primary objective is to provide accurate, relevant, and helpful responses.

**Core Instructions:**

1.  **Understand the Query and Context:** Thoroughly analyze the user's query and the provided retrieved graph information. Identify key entities, relationships, and the specific question being asked.
2.  **Synthesize and Answer:**
    *   If the retrieved information is **sufficient** to directly and comprehensively answer the query, synthesize the relevant facts into a clear, concise, and coherent response. Cite the source information implicitly by using the details provided.
    *   If the retrieved information is **partially sufficient**, answer as much of the query as possible based on the available data. Clearly state what information is present and what is missing.
3.  **Handle Insufficient Information:**
    *   If the retrieved information is **insufficient or irrelevant** to answer the query, **do not** provide a speculative or generic "I don't know" answer. Instead, explain *why* you cannot answer the query based on the provided context.
    *   **Guide the user:** Suggest what *additional information* or *type of query* might be needed to find an answer. For example, "The provided information discusses X but does not contain details about Y, which is needed to answer your question." or "To answer this, I would need information about [specific missing entity/relationship]."
4.  **Maintain Clarity and Conciseness:** Ensure your answers are easy to understand and avoid jargon where possible. Stick to the information available; do not introduce external knowledge or make assumptions beyond the provided context.
5.  **Prioritize Accuracy:** Base your answer solely on the facts presented in the retrieved graph information.

Your output should be a direct answer to the user's query or a helpful explanation of why the query cannot be answered with the given context, along with guidance for the user.

Would you like me to try searching for a general plot summary of [story name, if it was identified] from a broader source?" (This assumes the system has a fallback mechanism).

The retrieval plan demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of how to extract and utilize information from a graph for answering a query about a story's plot.

Here's a breakdown of the issues and how to improve:

**Critique of the Current Retrieval Plan:**

1.  **Node Listing vs. Plot Extraction:** The retrieved content consists solely of lists of nodes (characters and groups) with the constant statement that their connections "have not been explored yet." This is not context; it's a meta-description of an incomplete graph. A plot is about *events*, *relationships*, and *sequences of actions*, none of which are present in the retrieved "context."
2.  **Failure to Explore Edges/Relationships:** The core problem is that the LLM agent seems to have only identified entities (nodes) and failed to extract any relationships (edges) between them. The repeated "connections... have not been explored yet" is a direct admission of this failure. To understand a plot, the system *must* explore how characters interact, what they do, and what happens to them.
3.  **Redundancy and Lack of Progress:** Iterations 1, 2, and 4 provide identical, unhelpful information. Iterations 3, 5, and 6 return empty graphs, indicating a complete failure to extract any relevant data. There is no progression in understanding or gathering information across the iterations.
4.  **Irrelevant Search Strategy (Potentially):** While searching for "Person" nodes is a reasonable *first step* to identify characters, the plan stops there. The system needs to move beyond just identifying *who* is in the story to understanding *what they do*. Similarly, searching for "story" or "plot" keywords in nodes might yield titles or section headers but won't reveal the narrative itself.

**Recommendations for Improvement:**

1.  **Prioritize Edge Extraction:** The graph extraction process must focus on identifying *verbs* and *prepositional phrases* that describe actions, relationships, and causal links between entities. For example, "Captain Dietrich *defeated* the guards" should result in an edge between "Captain Dietrich" and "guards" labeled "defeated."
2.  **Implement Active Graph Exploration:** The LLM agent must actively query the graph for connections. This involves using functions to:
    *   Find neighbors of key entities.
    *   Identify the types of relationships (edges) connecting nodes.

**Recommendations for Improvement:**

1.  **Prioritize Edge Extraction:** The graph extraction process must focus on identifying *verbs* and *prepositional phrases* that describe actions, relationships, and causal links between entities. 6.  **Focus on Action and Consequence:** The goal is to understand *what is happening* in the story. This means identifying agents, actions, and targets, and how these elements link together through the graph's structure.

Start by identifying key entities or concepts from the query. Then, plan subsequent steps to explore their relationships, actions, and the sequence of events they are involved in. Always consider how to best leverage the graph's relational nature to reconstruct the story.

Here's a critique of the graph construction prompt, focusing on improving its effectiveness for plot extraction:

**Critique of the Graph Construction Prompt:**

The current prompt for graph construction, while attempting to capture entities and relationships, suffers from several critical limitations that directly impede its usefulness for plot extraction:

1.  **Insufficiently Granular Relationship Definition:** The prompt asks for "all the relationships among the identified entities" and a "description (why you think the two entities are related)." However, it doesn't explicitly guide the LLM to identify *action-oriented* and *causal* relationships that are the backbone of a plot. The resulting graph's broad and generic relationship types (as seen in the example critique: "interaction," "communication," "purpose") indicate that the LLM is either unable to infer specific actions or is prioritizing generic connections over plot-driving ones.

2.  **Lack of Focus on Event Sequencing and Causality:** A plot is fundamentally a sequence of events and their causal connections. The prompt does not explicitly instruct the LLM to identify events as distinct entities or to represent temporal ordering and causality between relationships. The graph exhibits several critical weaknesses that hinder its effectiveness for answering the query "What is the plot of the story?".

**1. Insufficient Depth of Relationship Exploration:**
The primary issue is the **lack of meaningful relationship extraction and exploration**. While the graph contains a large number of nodes and relationships (200 relationships for 117 nodes), the retrieval plans indicate a failure to traverse these connections meaningfully. The repeated statement "connections... have not been explored yet" signals a fundamental problem. A plot is inherently about the sequence of events and interactions between entities, which are represented by edges in the graph. The current approach seems to identify entities but does not delve into *what* they do or *how* they are connected beyond basic types.

**2. Generic and Overly Broad Relationship Types:**
The sheer volume and generic nature of relationship types listed are problematic. While there are many specific relationships (e.g., "knows reason for exile of"), there are also many single-occurrence, vague relationships like "interaction," "communication," "conflict," or "purpose." This indicates either an inability to extract more specific actions or an over-reliance on generic tags. For plot extraction, specific verbs describing actions and causal links are crucial.

**3. Ineffective Retrieval Strategy for Plot:**
The retrieval plan's focus on "Person" nodes as the primary starting point is a reasonable *initial step* to identify characters but is insufficient for understanding a plot. A plot is not just a list of characters; it's about their journey, conflicts, and resolutions. The agent needs to move beyond listing nodes to actively querying for sequences of actions, events, and causal chains. The repeated retrieval of identical, unhelpful information across iterations further emphasizes this flawed strategy.

**4. Lack of Contextual Granularity:**
The graph's description mentions "chunk size" being selected by an LLM, implying that the graph construction is tied to specific text segments. However, the current retrieval fails to demonstrate how these chunks are connected to form a coherent narrative. There's no apparent understanding of temporal order or causal links between events that might span across chunks.

Splitting the text into small chunks like this risks breaking up crucial sequences of actions, character interactions, or plot developments. For example, a character's decision in one sentence might be directly influenced by information presented in the preceding sentence. The LLM might default to extracting more generic relationships (like "interaction" or "conflict") because it lacks sufficient surrounding text to identify more specific actions or motivations. This contributes to the "Generic and Overly Broad Relationship Types" problem and hinders the ability to capture nuanced plot details.

**3. Inconsistent Entity and Relationship Representation:** Different chunks might contain different facets of the same entity or event. For instance, one chunk might introduce a character, another might describe their actions, and a third might detail their motivations. With a small chunk size, these distinct pieces of information might be processed independently, leading to fragmented representations of entities or relationships. Merging these can be difficult and might result in either redundant or incomplete information about a plot element. This impacts the ability to build a cohesive understanding required for plot summarization.

The "Lack of Contextual Granularity" is a direct consequence of this chunking strategy, as the temporal and causal flow of the story is disrupted at the chunk boundaries.

**Recommendation for Chunk Size:**

two landing stages are further along the beach, opposite the Temple of Uzdon." "Then we must hug to the shore until we pass the tip of the island," said Noork thoughtfully. "In that way even if they detect us we will have put a safe distance between us." Shortly after midday Noork felt the oozy slime of the marshy lowlands of the mainland beneath his paddle and the dugout ran ashore in the grassy inlet for which they had been heading. His palms were blistered and the heavy robes he yet wore were soaked with sweat. "Once we reach the jungle," he told the girl, "off come these robes. I am broiled alive." Suddenly Noork froze in his tracks. He thrust the girl behind him. "Misty Ones!" he hissed to Rold. "They crouch among the reeds. They carry nets and clubs to trap us." Rold turned back toward the boat with Noork and Sarna close at his heels. But the Misty Ones were upon them and by sheer numbers they bore them to the ground. Noork's mightier muscles smashed more than one hooded face but in the end he too lay smothered beneath the nets and bodies of the enemy. A misty shape came to stand beside these three new captives as they were stripped of their robes. His foot nudged at Noork's head curiously and a guttural voice commanded the shield be removed. Then his voice changedâ€”thickenedâ€”as he saw the features of Noork. "So," he barked in a tongue that should have been strange to Noork but was not, "it is the trapper's turn to be trapped, eh Captain Dietrich?" A fat, square-jawed face, harsh lines paralleling the ugly blob of a nose, showed through the opened robe of the leader. The face was that of Doctor Von Mark the treacherous Nazi scientist that Stephen Dietrich had trailed across space to Sekk! But Noork knew nothing of that chase. The man's face seemed familiar, and hateful, but that was all he remembered. "I see you have come from the island," said the Doctor. "Perhaps you can tell me the secret of this invisible material I wear. With the secret of invisibility I, Karl Von Mark, can again conquer Earth and make the Fatherland invincible." "I do not understand too well," said Noork hesitantly. "Are we enemies? There is so much I have forgotten." He regarded the brutal face thoughtfully. "Perhaps you know from what valley the great bird brought me," he said. "Or perhaps the other bird brought you here." Von Mark's blue eyes widened and then he roared with a great noise that was intended to be mirth. His foot slammed harder into Noork's defenseless ribs. "Perhaps you have forgotten, swine of an American," he roared suddenly, and in his hand was an ugly looking automatic. He flung back his robe and Noork saw the dress uniform of a general. "Perhaps," the scientist repeated, "but I will take no chances. The amnesia is often but a pretense." His lip curled. "This is something for you to remember, Captain Dietrich," he said as the ugly black muzzle of the gun centered on Noork's bronzed chest. And then Doctor Von Mark cursed as the gun dropped from his nerveless fingers and his hands clawed weakly at the arrow buried in his wide belly. He stumbled backward. Arrows rained from the mistiness that had closed in about Von Mark and his men. The men from Wari, their faces unshielded, fell like flies. In a moment those yet alive had taken to their heels, and Noork felt invisible fingers tearing at the nets that bound him. As he rose to his feet the robed figure let its misty covering drop aside. A handsome golden-skinned warrior stood revealed. "Gurn!" cried Noork. A glad cry came from the throat of Tholon Sarna as she saw her brother. And then she crept closer to Noork's side as the invisible mantles of Gurn's loyal Vasads opened to reveal the hairy beast men they concealed. Rold whimpered fearfully. "The message that Ud carried to me was good," laughed Gurn. "The Misty Ones skin easily. We were trapping the Misty Ones as they came across the lake," he looked at the dying Von Mark, "as were these others. Soon we would have come to your rescue, Noork, my friend." "Lucky I escaped first," Noork told him. "The priests of Uzdon would have trapped you. To them the Misty Ones are visible." He picked up the fallen vision shield that lay beside their feet. His chest expanded proudly. "No longer," he told Gurn, "am I a man without a name. I am Captain Dietrich from a distant valley called America. I was hunting this evil man when my bird died." He smiled and his brown arm tightened around Sarna's golden body. "The evil man is dead. My native valley is safe. Now I can live in peace with you, Gurn, and with your sister, here in the jungle." "It is good, Noork," smiled Tholon Sarna. End of Project Gutenberg's Raiders of the Second Moon, by Gene Ellerman
